title: META-NET: Towards the Multilingual Europe Technology Alliance

author: Hans Uszkoreit, German Research Center for Artificial Intelligence (DFKI)

Yeah, there's quite some opposition building up here.
On the one hand, it's true right now Europe could save some money, but very little money because we don't get much here in language technology.
On the other hand.
Costs that could come up with neglecting this area, taking the sensitivity of language communities when it comes to their cultural identity could be quite drastic.

Yeah, so in the end, language communities as we know from many parts of the world, they are able to not only spend money on their language, but also to do bloodshed, to fight, to destroy cities, to do anything to maybe reject the next Treaty of the European Union.
And veto it to do anything to keep their identity.

So here we really have a problem because Europe, as opposed to the other superpowers of the world to the United States, to Japan, to China, is not a mainly predominant monolingual SoC, but Europe has made this promise that even the smallest of our languages in Europe is important enough to be kept and preserved, and this would cost a little money.
And in another talk I calculated that.
Actually, our field just needs the tiny some that it cost to build 93 kilometers of Hwy around, namely 500,500 million euro for the next years would suffice to make a bigger push in this area.
And this is just a tiny little drop of money for the you for the major challenges are clear, it's preserving the European cultural and linguistic diversity secure.
Ring at affordable cost.

The free flow of information and thought across languages and then not only the cross lingual aspect but also providing each language community with the most advanced technologies for communication, information and knowledge management so that maintaining the mother tongue does not turn into a disk.
Advantage so that people don't regret later on that they followed this.
So where are we today?
Yes, of course we are researchers and of course we have been successful, at least partially.
So research has made considerable progress in recent years.
Successful projects have been funded by EU national programs others, but the pace of progress is really too slow.
It's not fast enough to meet the three challenges I just mentioned within the next 10 to 20 years, but this is very important time.
This is when the digital SoC the.

Common Digital, the single digital market develops, and so there's no way that with the current pace of progress, we will be able to really provide the necessary technological means for not even the 23 official languages leave alone.

The 57 or so languages of Europe that really want to survive can progress be accelerated, yes, but only if the relevant stakeholders such as research communities, the language, technology, industry, user industries, language communities, funding programs, policy makers, team up.
Two and two, a joint.
Not that every work has to be joined, clearly not.
There will be lots of different lots of different strengths of research, technology development, market exploration, market penetration.
But nevertheless we need first to team up because otherwise the type of subsidy that this mainly SMB oriented SME centered sector of economy needs.
The subsidy won't get.
Many other areas have this subsidy and have much stronger subsidies here.
When you think of the European airplane industry.
And and automobile industry is heavily subsidized by countries now, but the language technology industry really is not.
It's heavily underfunded.
So how can we form such an alliant?
So how can we as researchers now?
We also I'm a researcher.
How can I do it?
I mean, as many of you are from industry or you have all the power you don't have the time, you know, but you have all the power you could do it and so how can we together do it?
Yeah.

But then in addition you need some visions and plans just with a bunch of individual project proposals.
Nobody is going to give us these 500 million nobody because we need something more.
We need a strategic research agenda and then you get the visibility credibility you get massive support and then it feeds back.
And as already indicated, there are good examples from other areas.
There are other errors and other technology fields who have done this already who have formed this type of alliance, sometimes strengthened by the fact that more large.
Organizations large multinational companies are part of these technology areas.
We only have them in the user industries there.
We also have them here, but they teamed up and they got there.

They use completely different instruments, but in the end here they managed to get up.

The Alliance and Metanet now tries to establish.
This alliance so the meta net is just a network of excellence, and it has three major objectives.

First, to prepare the grounds for this large scale concerted effort by trying to bring together the Strategic alliance, then strengthen the European research community through networking of research, sharing resources and efforts.
Here we are on a line with other initiatives like Flarenet claren like Towers, many others we need to kind of combine our efforts and then build bridges.
By approaching open problems and research in collaboration with other research fields such as Miss.
Team learning social computing, cognitive systems, cognitive science, knowledge technologies, multimedia content so that we are better connected there and this network got some initial funding.
So 6 million Euro contribution and it's funded for three years.
And maybe it's not by mistake funded at a time when the eight framework program is being prepared and many other things happen in Europe.
And there's no one project funded under Metanet, but there are other projects in the making.
Whether they will be funded, we will see we will be there.
Let's be optimistic there other proposals and they are looked at now and evaluated carefully.
And if we are lucky then we will have a couple of more.

Those are the funding members.
